org.beiter.michael.eaudit4j.common

Interface Processor


  • public interface Processor
    A processor can be part of an input / output sequence of processors. When an event is submitted to a processor, then it processes (e.g. modifies or persists) the event. The output of a first processor may be used as the input of a second processor in a audit chain.

    Classes implementing this interface must be thread safe.

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • init

        void init(CommonProperties properties)
        Initializes the configuration of an audit processor.

        A class implementing this interface may provide a reasonable default configuration and handle situations where e.g. the process() methods are called without a previous call of init() (i.e. do not throw any exception), but this is not guaranteed (i.e. calling the process() methods without proper initialization may throw an exception, such as an IllegalStateException or a AuditException).

        A class implementing this interface must ensure that subsequent calls to this method update the class' configuration in a thread-safe way.

        Parameters:
        properties - The properties to initialize the audit processor with. Supported "additionalParameters" may vary with the implementing classes.

      • process

        Event process(Event event)
       throws AuditException
        Audit an event within the default audit stream obtained from the configuration.

        Implementations of this method may change the event, for instance, by adding new fields to the event, or modifying existing fields in the event.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to be processed
        Returns:
        The event after processing (including modifications to the original event)
        Throws:
        AuditException - When the event cannot be processed

      • process

        Event process(Event event,
              String auditStreamName)
       throws AuditException
        Audit an event within the provided audit stream.

        Applications may support more than one audit streams. Audit streams are event streams that are isolated from each other. As an example, an application may want to support one audit stream per tenant, plus one or more additional audit streams for global events, allowing sharing of audit data with tenants without the risk of compromising other tenants but still maintaining full integrity of the shared audit data.

        Implementations of this method may change the event, for instance, by adding new fields to the event, or modifying existing fields in the event.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to be processed
        auditStreamName - The audit stream to send events to
        Returns:
        The event after processing (including modifications to the original event)
        Throws:
        AuditException - When the event cannot be processed

      • process

        Event process(Event event,
              String auditStreamName,
              ProcessingObjects processingObjects)
       throws AuditException
        Audit an event within the provided audit stream and a set of ProcessingObjects.

        ProcessingObjects allow an application to inject a set of named objects into the processor. This is commonly used for objects that are managed by applications, and cannot or should not be created by an individual Processor.

        Examples for such objects include DataSource objects to connect to a database, with the database connection pool being managed directly by the application.

        Implementations of this method may change the event, for instance, by adding new fields to the event, or modifying existing fields in the event.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to be processed
        auditStreamName - The audit stream to send events to
        processingObjects - The processing objects available to the processor
        Returns:
        The event after processing (including modifications to the original event)
        Throws:
        AuditException - When the event cannot be processed

      • cleanUp

        void cleanUp()
        Clean up temporary data / keys / etc
